The SPEAKER ( Hon.
Milton Dick ) took the chair at 10:00, made an acknowledgement of country and read prayers.
COMMITTEES
Petitions Committee
Report

Ms
TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I present the 15th report of the Petitions Committee for the 47th Parliament.
Chair Ms Susan Templeman MP
Deputy Chair Mr Ross Vasta MP
Mr Sam Birrell MP
Ms Alison Byrnes MP
Ms Lisa Chesters MP
Mr Garth Hamilton MP
Ms Tracey Roberts MP
Ms Meryl Swanson MP
This committee is supported by staff of the Department of the House of Representatives

span.span: Report summarising the petitions and ministerial responses being presented.
The committee met in private session in the 47th Parliament on 2 August 2023 and 9 August 2023
1. The committee resolved to present the following 72 petitions in accordance with standing order 207:

PETITIONS
Presentation
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I present the following 72 petitions:
Age Pension

The reason I am starting a new petition is that like many others once we reach 65 our health starts to deteriorate and our mental sharpness is not the same. We have worked in Australia and paid taxes and raised kids on our own for some of uss 45 years. Now we're told to work till we're 67 and it will go up. This is grossly discriminatory on older Australians. We deserve a fair go. Plus employers don't really want 65+ and they treat us with disrespect.
We therefore ask the House to please reduce the age pension back to 65.
from 83 citizens (Petition No. EN5224)
Food Labelling

As the WHOs international agency for research on cancer (IARC) has labelled glycophosphate (active ingredient in roundup) a probable carcinogen, and such is linked to a myriad of health consequences, it's high time that safety labels are placed on foods containing such poisons.
It would also be fantastic to see the government step in and ban the use of roundup as a dessicant on crops just prior to harvest. This is common sense stuff.

We therefore ask the House to set about implementing changes so that foods containing glycophosphate (at any level) are mandated to have labels informing the consumer of such. Also, a ban on spraying crops with roundup as a dessicant prior to harvest.
from 56 citizens (Petition No. EN5225)
Financial Transactions

There are increasing numbers of businesses in Australia who are refusing to accept legal Australian tender i.e., cash, cheques etc. This is immoral and needs to be illegal. The people of Australia should have the right to pay for goods and services using any form of legal Australian Tender of their choice.
We therefore ask the House to legislate that any business operating in Australia must accept any and all forms of legal Australian tender.
from 501 citizens (Petition No. EN5226)
Electric Vehicles

Thanks to the ABC recently airing 2 shows on the issues with EVs. Privately owned EVs spend on average, 10 to 12 hours overnight on charge using electricity from the grid. They are contributing 70 to 80 hours of coal fired emissions into the environment every week just to get people to work and back. More extensive trips require even more charging and using high-capacity chargers just makes the situation worse. Compared to fuel driven vehicles which travel an average of an hour per day getting people to work and back, which are putting 7 or so hours per week of well controlled fuel emissions into the environment each week. 70 to 80 hours per week as compared to 7 hours per week. Anyone who cares about the environment would not drive an EV.
We therefore ask the House to ban EVs from our roads unless the owner can demonstrate that they are charged from a source other than the electricity grid.
from 13 citizens (Petition No. EN5227)
Energy

Australia needs to increase the use of gas cooking appliances in order to take pressure off the electricity grid. Gas is cost effective, gas is readily available, and gas burns cleanly making it much less damaging to the environment than the production of electricity. The Federal Government needs to provide financial incentives to the people in order to increase the use of gas cooking appliances.
We therefore ask the House to provide a subsidy to encourage people to use gas cooking appliances. Perhaps a subsidy for each new home constructed that has gas cooking installed could be approved.
from seven citizens (Petition No. EN5228)
Parental Leave
Equal rights: The requirement unfairly discriminates against new parents who recently changed jobs or entered the workforce, denying them equal access to parental leave.
Family well-being: Parental leave is crucial for newborns or newly adopted children, promoting bonding and ensuring their well-being during their early and formative years.

Career mobility: The requirement forces new parents to choose between career advancement and their parental responsibilities, limiting their ability to pursue new opportunities or address unforeseen circumstances.
Progressive policies: Removing the barrier aligns with the trend towards more inclusive and supportive parental leave policies, reflecting the evolving needs and values of society.

We therefore ask the House to iew the minimum 12-month requirement at a new employer before allowing parental leave. This requirement places an unfair burden on new parents, hindering their ability to care for their children during their early and formative years.

Parental leave is a crucial right that facilitates bonding and ensures the well-being of newborns or newly adopted children. However, the current regulation disproportionately affects those who recently changed jobs or entered the workforce, forcing them to choose between career advancement and parental responsibilities.

We believe that the right to parental leave should not depend on employment duration. All parents, regardless of their tenure at a new employer, should have the opportunity to take leave and prioritize their children's well-being.
We respectfully request that the House review and revise the existing regulations to ensure fair and equitable access to parental leave for all parents.
from seven citizens (Petition No. EN5229)
Coal Seam Gas Mining

Water is life. It is life to our communities, our environment, our farming and tourism industries. Gas mining poisons our water. The main byproduct of mining CSG in Australia is salt, which is already the number one agent of soil degradation globally. CSG salt also contains highly toxic poisons and carcinogens including BTEX chemicals, radioactive materials and arsenic. A site at Chinchilla QLD has been approved to take FIFTEEN MILLION TONNES of this toxic salt, to be stored in glorified landfill 50 metres uphill from Rocky Creek in the catchment of the Murray Darling basin and the Great Artesian Basin it feeds.
The recent QLD Government Ten Year Brine Management Plan and expert studies have shown the site and present technology will not safely contain the poison.
Salt is a persistent poison. It does not break down. Recent floods have shown just how far this salt will poison when it leaks.
Until this salt can be safely stored long-term, all CSG mining must stop immediately.
We therefore ask the House to ban all Coal Seam Gas mining until a safe long-term salt storage technology can be created.
from 732 citizens (Petition No. EN5230)

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Constitution: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice

p.span: Australian Constitution: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice

The proposed Voice Referendum is a threat to Australia's democracy, undermines our one vote democratic system and will divide the Australian society permanently based on race which is inconsistent with the great unified multicultural society Australia has established. We the undersigned vigorously oppose and do not consent to a referendum and reject a 'yes' vote. We express our overwhelming concern, herewith:
*The 1967 referendum already recognised our First Nations people.
*Is NOT representative as many First Nations peoples have been ignored, silenced, or not consulted; yet their voices are loudly and clearly warning 'no'.
*It's divisive and would create a constitutional preference for one group of Australians over another. It's wrong to enshrine division in our Constitution.
*It's unnecessary as our Constitution upholds that every Australian is equal before the law.
*There's no detailed information on the legal implications and impacts to Australians, without specifics, all votes are invalid.
*The $364m starting cost, when Australians are struggling with inflation, cost of living and interest rate hikes.
*300 Indigenous representative bodies already exist with $1.9b of funding committed costing taxpayers $100m a day.
*The Voice makes recognition conditional on approving the Voice, it's manipulative, pressuring people to think voting 'no' means they're racist.
*It's a platform for radical activists to attack our values and institutions.
*The Voice referendum proposal by government are in direct violation of the REFERENDUM ACT 1984—SECT 11, 4, 122.
We therefore ask the House to vote against the Voice Referendum as our democracy thrives when it unites rather than divides us.
from 1,893 citizens (Petition No. EN5231)
Citizenship

A lack of vision by the Government, when introducing much-needed legislative change in 2002, has thrown countless Australians into legal limbo regarding their citizenship status. Australian citizens who acquired a second citizenship before 2002 have fallen foul of s17. Most who acquired another citizenship probably did so for cultural reasons, and for ease of travel to—and temporary residency in—a nation to which they almost certainly had close, familial ties. To have elected to acquire a second citizenship should not be interpreted as an indication such a person no longer wished to be Australian. Yet this is precisely the erroneous view taken by the Australian Government of the day, and not corrected by any subsequent Government.
Noteworthy facts:
• s17 was repealed in 2002, indicating the government has not viewed dual citizenship as problematic for over two decades.
• The 2015 and subsequent amendments evidence the Government recognises the threshold for stripping an Australian of their Australian citizenship is higher than simply holding another citizenship.
Not taking steps to remedy this situation leads to other issues, including:
• The legal status of any official documentation signed by affected people.
• The status of their children and grandchildren.
• The situation for those working in jobs for which Australian citizenship is mandatory.

The Australian Government does not—and cannot—know who is affected by this. Many affected people themselves are unaware. The current situation is not tenable and would be remedied by the repeal of s17 with retrospective effect.
We therefore ask the House to repeal s17 of the Citizenship Act 1948 with retrospective effect.
from 18 citizens (Petition No. EN5232)
COVID-19: Vaccination

Thanks to new peer reviewed studies, we now know that the risks associated with both Pfizer and Moderna's Sars-CoV-2 mRNA vaccines are much higher than initially thought. The risk of serious adverse advents has been shown to be higher than vaccine's which have been rejected for use in the past such as the Swine Flu vaccine (1976) and Rotavirus Vaccine (1999). Therefore, it is inhumane and simply wrong to continue use of these vaccines until further analysis of new data can be performed. At present, there is potential unacceptable risk to the Australian Public associated with the current Sars-CoV-2 mRNA Vaccines.
We therefore ask the House to pause use of Pfizer and Moderna Sars-CoV-2 mRNA vaccines nation wide immediately so that new data can be evaluated by the TGA and appropriate bodies.
from 82 citizens (Petition No. EN5233)
Disability Support Pension
DSP is a dismal $971.50, or up to roughly $1200 per fortnight if you include other minor benefits such as rent assistance, telephone allowance etc.
This creates a huge class gap. $480-$600 per week is barely enough to cover daily living expenses, let alone the added costs of having a disability.

To make matters worse, the extremely low income automatically excludes disabled Australians from being able to own a home, as no bank would lend such a high amount to someone with such a low income, especially when it's impossible to save when your basic everyday expenses are barely covered—if at all.

We therefore ask the House to increase DSP to be brought up to AT MINIMUM, the equivalent of minimum wage at 40 hours per week. A disabled person cannot work, and should not be treated as "less than". We have no opportunity to increase our income, through no fault of our own. The minimum wage is supposed to be enough to live a dignified life with minimal luxuries, but for some reason we don't deserve to be paid what we would be paid if we WERE able to work.
from 11 citizens (Petition No. EN5235)
Road Safety
Recent tragedy in the Hunter Valley, and in support of numerous parents with children travelling in school buses every day. Something needs to change in honour of their pain.
We therefore ask the House to urgently review the mandatory installation and enforcement for wearing of seat belts in any vehicle on roads in Australia.
from 9,795 citizens (Petition No. EN5237)
Housing

There is not a consistent approach to rent increases in Australia and in many cases there is no limit on the amount that rent can be increased. In 2023 we are seeing unprecedented increases in rent and other cost of living expenses, at times forcing Australians from their homes when they are no longer able to afford their rent. This is not an acceptable situation.

We therefore ask the House to introduce federal legislation to guide and achieve a consistent approach across all States and Territories. The outcome should be limits placed on rent increases and the frequency of increases that are fair and realistic for all Australians.
from 616 citizens (Petition No. EN5239)
Discrimination

Petition for Proposed 'Mercy Amendment' to the Corporations Act 2001 (Cth) Appeal for reformed scope to 'whistleblowing' protections for victims of disability discrimination Concern: i.The Corporations Act 2001 (Cth) provides scope for whistleblowing with relation to financial misconduct or other legislative breaches that carry 1 year imprisonment. However, the maximum penalty under the Disability Discrimination Act 1992 (Cth) is 6 months. As an Australian, it does raise an ethical question regarding why financial misconduct carries greater weight than a human rights breach, such as disability discrimination. Further, these human rights breaches cannot be whistle-blown.

We therefore ask the House to consider the proposed solution: The 'Mercy Amendment' to the Corporations Act 2001 (Cth) i.That an amendment to the Corporations Act 2001 (Cth) be actioned that specifies that suspected human rights breaches, whether substantiated by the employer or not, no longer fall under the category of 'personal grievance,' but rather, 'potential breach.' ii.That the aforementioned amendment specifies that a whistleblower disclosure, and legislative protection of the whistleblower, be afforded in the case of suspected human rights violations including disability discrimination; even if the maximum imprisonment specified within that legislation be less than 1 year. iii.That the victim of the human rights breach, in this instance disability discrimination, also has protections as a whistleblower. v.That employees, and their colleague whistleblowers, who have been historically impacted by disability discrimination be afforded protections under the proposed 'Mercy Amendment.'
from four citizens (Petition No. EN5240)
Housing

Land is plentiful in Australia. The problem is jobs are centralised to capital cities where housing is unaffordable, especially Sydney & Melbourne. People live where they can travel to their jobs. We can solve the housing crisis by connecting far away vacant land to capital cities using Elon Musk's 1200km/hr Hyperloop. National Parks are not privately owned meaning the government can sell the land for next to nothing—Land and home packages at these locations would be extremely affordable. Oil & Gas company's operating within Australia evade paying up to 30 billion in tax/royalties compared to countries like Norway, Qatar and the UK.

We therefore ask the House to support the idea of building, from ground up, the greatest city the world has ever seen, at Mount Kosciuszko National Park, connected to Sydney (20 mins) & Melbourne (18mins), using Elon Musk's 1200km/hr Hyperloop, paid for by collecting an extra 25 billion in tax/royalties every year from Oil & Gas company's operating within Australia.
from three citizens (Petition No. EN5241)
Economy

Australia's currency is a commodity currency. Google "Graph, AUD vs Commodity Prices," almost a perfect correlation. Interest rate rises or cuts have minimal impact on the AUD, meaning a broader approach can be utilised when dealing with inflation or stimulating the economy. A compulsory savings mechanism for high income individuals (Meaning they have less to spend in the economy, causing inflation to cool), would give the RBA an additional tool. If, in the future our economy slows, these high income individuals would gain access to their savings, stimulating the economy. Australia's treasurer is the only individual with the power to overrule the RBA.

We therefore ask the House to support the idea of a compulsory savings mechanism for high income individuals as an additional tool to fight inflation, allowing less emphasis to be placed on the interest rate mechanism. We also ask the House to support the idea that our treasurer uses his unique power to overrule many of the RBA's recent interest rate rises, effectively lowering the rate to 2.5% or thereabouts.
from four citizens (Petition No. EN5242)
Disability Parking
Discrimination of disabled parking for persons holding authorised disability parking permit.
These offences are ongoing in Australia in breach of the Federal Disability Discrimination Act 1992
These offences deny an authorised permit holder access to the community.

There is conclusive evidence available that able bodied drivers without permits are committing offences against Federal Legislation by knowingly and illegally occupying Disability Parking Bays Displaying International Symbol of Access

We therefore ask the House to validate the Federal Legislation under the Disability Discrimination Act 1992 ensuring that all States and Territories of Australia have the proper authority to initiate actions with regard to offenders occupying the designated disability parking bays displaying the International Symbol of Access
from 185 citizens (Petition No. EN5243)
AUKUS
We consider that the $368 billion cost for eight submarines is outrageous. And at a time when Australia has a $900 billion debt we do not need more.

As a member of the trilateral AUKUS pact Australia will now be more of a target in the event of war (especially one between China and the US/UK). This will be especially so if we have any form of nuclear capability. Rather than being a deterrent we believe that having nuclear submarines will make Australia more of a target.

The $32 million per day—for thirty one (31) years—can be much better spent on housing, health care, education, remedying other social and criminal problems (drugs, child/domestic abuse, energy and environmental issues) and improving the lot of the three million Australians that currently live below the poverty line.
We therefore ask the House to please withdraw from the AUKUS submarine agreement.
from 25 citizens (Petition No. EN5246)
Housing
Australian government need to prioritise its Australian citizens and permanent residents. the housing crisis has caused a shortage of real estate.

forhen investors capitalise on this buying up realestate outright and renting it out causing a shortage of houses for citizens and permanent residents. this has a flow on effect essentially causing Australian dollars to leave the country going into the pockets of forhen investors.

to protect and provide housing to australian citizens and permanent residents the Australian government should priritize its citizens by introducing a law stating you must be a resident or citizen of Australia to purchase realestate.
We therefore ask the House to establish a rule that states you must be a permanent resident or Australian citizen to purchase housing realestate in Australia.
from 44 citizens (Petition No. EN5247)

subdebateinfo.title: Physical and Sexual Harassment and Violence

p.span: Physical and Sexual Harassment and Violence

The current climate of the justice system for sexual violence survivors is shrouded in victim-blaming, stigma towards men and minorities and a lack of understanding for how to navigate conversations in a trauma-informed way. The justice system is incredibly retraumatising, and there is a lack of understanding about dissociative amnesia in regards to cases- the process by which survivors block out trauma- and how the brain responds to danger. There is a lack of comprehensive information for police, which is bountifully available for mental health clinicians, but not those who deal with both the perpetrator and victim. I implore that training covers how to validate and provide autonomy to survivors—including psychologist-approved and survivor-approved training and exams into conversations. Conversation guides would include phrasing such as "I believe you" and how to distinguish victim wellbeing from legal aspects, whereby there may be insufficient evidence. Understanding how the brain blocks out trauma should also be included in this mandated training, to allow for a more compassionate and suitable approach allowing the survivor to remember and process their trauma in a safe environment. It is not enough for police to just know what legal steps to take. Police have the power to either halt or propel healing no matter the legal outcome, and hence our police need to be informed about how trauma is blocked out, and about the best practices to avoid retraumatisation.
We therefore ask the House to mandate trauma-informed police training and exams in recruitment, comprehensively ensuring wellbeing.
from 22 citizens (Petition No. EN5250)
Pensions and Benefits
Potential abuse of support programs such as Central Link and other grants by certain individuals or groups within the immigrant community.
It is crucial to tackle this issue to ensure a fair and equitable distribution of resources and to foster a balanced and thriving society.

Some immigrant groups exploit loopholes within the system, taking advantage of government payments and support without actively seeking employment. Resulting in such individuals or groups solely relying on government assistance, without making contributions to the tax system, and potentially availing community housing indefinitely.
Such abuses not only place an undue burden on the government but also hinder economic growth and exacerbate social inequality.

Therefore, we respectfully request that immediate action be taken to limit support for Central Link and other grants to individuals or groups who are not actively seeking employment and who may be exploiting the system

We therefore ask the House to o record and ensure compliance with tax regulations, so we can identify those exploiting the system and evading their tax responsibilities. Furthermore, based on the results of the investigation, I propose the implementation of an appropriate rating system for these groups. This rating system would take into account factors such as tax compliance, active employment seeking, and responsible utilization of government support programs. By implementing this system, we can allocate resources and benefits more effectively, ensuring that those who actively contribute to society and fulfill their obligations are prioritized and rewarded accordingly.
from four citizens (Petition No. EN5251)
Gender Dysphoria
Gender Affirmation care should not be covered by Medicare as it is NOT for medical treatment and should not be paid under gender care.
We therefore ask the House to stop Medicare to pay for this.
from 31 citizens (Petition No. EN5252)
Environment

As a concerned citizen of Australia, I would like to bring attention to a matter of great significance, that affects not only the well being of our community, but also the larger environmental and public health concerns that we collectively share.

It has come to my attention, along with numerous other concerned citizens, that there exists compelling evidence indicating the deployment of substantial quantities of unidentified chemicals into our atmosphere by various entities, including Government military, commercial and private planes. The frequency and scale of these operations are unprecedented, causing the widespread apprehension among the general public.

Regrettably , as citizens, we find ourselves deprived of complete disclosure regarding the objectives and composition of these chemical deployments. The lack of transparent information on this matter prevents us from comprehending the purpose behind these activities, as well as the potential ramifications they may have on our health and the environment.

Given the absence of publicly scientific evidence to support or refute the effects of these chemicals on public health and the environment, we find ourselves in a precarious position. It is our firm belief that such crucial matters should not be left unaddressed, and it is incumbent upon the responsible authorities to shed light on this issue and provide the necessary information to the public.
We therefore ask the House to :
1- Initiate a comprehensive and independent investigation.
2- Ensure findings are made public.
3- implement measures to enhance public awareness and engagement, to actively participate in the dialogue surrounding potential consequences.
from 4,968 citizens (Petition No. EN5255)

Trans and gender-diverse people in need of gender-affirming surgery must pay a lot of money, up to $110,000 for bottom gender-affirmation surgery to obtain legal Australian gender-recognition birth certificates and other legal gender-affirmation identification to access our Australian citizenship rights.

Without gender affirmation surgery being covered by Medicare this prevents gender affirmation surgeons from being trained in Australia. This forces many trans and gender diverse people to have to go on long waiting lists for free top surgeries or get illegal backyard bottom surgeries through the black market or go overseas to access affordable gender affirmation surgeries in Canada and the UK not available in Australia.

Without gender affirmation surgery being covered by Medicare this puts many trans and gender diverse people in a situation of being denied a birth certificate or other legal identification in states and territories that require gender affirmation surgery to obtain Australian birth certificates and legal identification. This results in many trans and gender-diverse people experiencing high levels of discrimination, bullying, deadnaming, misgendering, abuse, neglect, vilification, and hate as well as many other physical health problems in being denied Australian citizenship rights to employment, education, welfare, affordable housing, healthcare etc without gender affirmation surgery to obtain identification records to reflect a transgender person's name and gender.

We therefore ask the House to make gender-affirming and gender reassignment services eligible for Medicare benefits, as these surgeries are essential for the health and well-being of Trans and gender-diverse people in the LGBTQA+ community.

from 24 citizens (Petition No. EN5257)

Violating the code could result in penalties up to $2.75 million dollars or 2 per cent of global turnover—whichever is greater. According to the draft bill, misinformation is defined as unintentionally false, misleading or deceptive content. however, during the pandemic we saw that any information that went against the narrative or made the government look bad was branded "misinformation", even if it was true, while government disinformation (for example, branding people who opposed lockdowns, mask mandates and vaccine mandates "far-right extremists") was allowed to proliferate unchecked. If the legislation is passed, these new powers will be abused. Free speech will be restricted and inconvenient truths will be suppressed. There are also privacy concerns around requiring social media platforms to disclose records regarding misinformation and disinformation, potentially leading to persecution of individual dissidents.
We therefore ask the House to reject the Communications Legislation Amendment (Combatting Misinformation and Disinformation) Bill 2023.

RIM, which has affiliations across Europe and the US, offers training in urban warfare, psyops and tactical medicine to extremists and neo-Nazis across the globe, including those who committed bombings in Sweden in 2016. RIM members don't recognise Ukraine as a country and have fought with pro-Russians in the Donbas since July 2014, as well as fought as mercenaries in the Middle East and North Africa. from 12 citizens (Petition No. EN5304)
Housing

The housing crisis in Australia is a multifaceted problem characterized by soaring property prices, rising rental costs, and a scarcity of affordable housing options. Short-term rentals, such as those facilitated by Airbnb, represent only a small part of this larger crisis. However, they contribute significantly to the diminishing availability and affordability of housing, exacerbating the problem for long-term residents. The conversion of residential properties into lucrative short-term rentals reduces the stock of long-term rental properties, making it increasingly difficult for individuals and families to secure stable housing. While regulations or a potential ban on short-term rentals alone may not solve the housing crisis, addressing this aspect is a crucial step toward creating a more equitable and sustainable housing market that prioritises the needs of long-term residents.

We therefore ask the House to draw inspiration from the successful example of state cooperation following the mass shooting in Port Arthur, which led to the creation of the National Firearms Agreement. This cooperative effort resulted in effective gun-control measures, we implore the government to harness the power of the National Cabinet to address the issue of short-term rentals. We request that the government, if federal regulation or a ban is not immediately feasible, add the regulation or banning of short-term rentals to the National Cabinet's agenda. By fostering collaboration and unity among all levels of government, we can work towards comprehensive solutions to alleviate the housing crisis and create a fair and sustainable housing market that prioritises the long-term well-being of Australian citizens.
from 59 citizens (Petition No. EN5307)
Pensions and Benefits

Universal Basic Income is an unconditional, universal, periodic cash payment to every adult in a society, regardless of circumstances. It can better meet Australians' welfare needs than our combined programs of targeted, means-tested income support.

The latter require a vast bureaucracy to administer programs and assess claimants, and make vulnerable people negotiate complex, arduous processes to access support. We end up with a costly, inefficient and ineffective system that, by trying to avoid a few getting help they don't need leaves many needing help they don't get, while stigmatizing those that do.
Further, we waste resources trying to patch up downstream impacts—harmful society-wide effects of poverty and insecurity—instead of just preventing them in the first place.

UBI—understood simply as one's share of the common inheritance, rather than welfare or charity—removes the stigma from income support, while assuring everyone of the same, secure foundation upon which to build their lives.

UBI is an upstream investment in human capital with high ROI (e.g., every dollar spent reducing child poverty returns ~$8 economic benefit), yielding more in savings and benefits than it costs. Across many trials worldwide, benefits consistently include:
Financial: more savings, home ownership.
Health: improved physical and mental health; reduced hospitalization.
Education: improved learning, graduation rates, earnings.
Crime: reduced crime, DV.
Employment: steady labour supply; increased self-employment, entrepreneurship, productivity.
Trust & social cohesion: increased trust in government, interpersonal trust.
We therefore ask the House to set up a parliamentary committee to investigate the merits of all Australian adults receiving Universal Basic Income.

Universities

Research students are essential to our country's innovative industries and are the future leaders of our workforce. However, the current national stipend of $32,500 per year is not enough to cover even the most basic living expenses. When considering the average 50 hours of work per week for 50 weeks per year this kind of research often takes, this equates to a meagre hourly rate of $13. Even at the national working hour average of 38 hours per week, the hourly rate is still only $17.10. The national minimum hourly rate is now $23.23. Research students do not receive paid sick leave or personal time off either, and are expected to take unpaid leave instead. This lack of support forces many students to seek part-time employment to supplement their stipend, which negatively impacts their research and increases their stress levels, leading to a higher risk of mental health issues. Many talented individuals are forced to abandon their studies because they cannot afford to support themselves, their families, or cover basic expenses.

We therefore ask the House to provide a minimum living wage to Master and PhD research students by raising the stipend payments to $44,137 per year, equivalent to the minimum wage for 38 hours of work per week for 50 weeks. This will significantly improve the quality of life for thousands of Australian research students. This investment will ensure that our country's innovation is supported and our future leaders are empowered.
from 58 citizens (Petition No. EN5321)

We therefore ask the House to provide a financial analysis report of all organisations, corporations, bodies, agencies and entities funded by the Australian taxpayer that provide services to Aboriginal Australians. The analysis to provide a single combined report which identifies the dollar value provided to each entity (specifically identifying each organisation, corporation, body, agency and entity) receiving funding, how much of this funding is used internally by the funded organisation, corporation, body, agency and entity such as wages and other operating costs etc and how much of this funding then directly supports aboriginals after internal entity costs.

The report is to be detailed in such a transparent manner that Australians can see in a numerical dollar value the cost of this funding and how much of this funding then directly benefits Australian Aboriginals.
from 673 citizens (Petition No. EN5324)
Defence Personnel

The Ombudsman Amendment (Defence Reparation Scheme) Regulations 2020 (an amendment to the Ombudsman Regulations 2017 (Regulations)) provided a time-limited extension of the Defence Reparation Scheme, which expired (after a brief extension) on 30 June 2022. The aim of that amendment to the Regulations was to ensure that complainants could make contact with the Defence Force Ombudsman and potentially still be able to receive a reparation payment (in certain circumstances).

Abuse in the military is a serious matter. Complainants must be given ample opportunity to make their complaints known and there should be a further extension to the time limits for lodging new complaints.

Access to this scheme was not advertised / communicated effectively or broadly enough and many potential complainants have been deprived of their opportunity to lodge a complaint and to have their complaints assessed by the Ombudsman.
We therefore ask the House to (respectfully) to further amend the Ombudsman Regulations 2017, by amending regulation 14(1B)(b) to read:
(b) either:
(i) the complaint is made to the Defence Force Ombudsman on or before 31 December 2025; or

(ii) a written notice of intention to make the complaint is given to the Defence Force Ombudsman on or before 31 December 2025 and the complaint is made to the Defence Force Ombudsman on or before 30 June 2026.
from 391 citizens (Petition No. EN5328)
Banking and Financial Services
In today's digitised economy access to banking is a human right. Removal of banking services excommunicates a person from Australian society and inflicts serious and acute personal harm.
Banks must not be allowed to deny financial services to customers unless explicitly required by law.
We therefore ask the House to pass legislation that enshrines a person's right to access financial services. This means:
1. Every Australian citizen has a right to a working bank account.
2. Australians may conduct any lawful financial transaction, free of interference by a financial institution.
3. Banks may not freeze funds, refuse transactions, or deny banking services unless required by law or to protect a customer from identity theft.
4. Australians are entitled to conduct financial transactions through the banks using any lawful means, including cash.
5. Banks may not employ any coercive means to compel customers to use any form of legal tender other than that preferred by the customer.
6. Whenever a bank decides to withdraw any existing financial service it must provide affected customers with 90 days written notice in advance.
7. If a bank decides to restrict an individual customer's account it must immediately provide the customer a written list of reasons why.
8. Customers are entitled to demand that data held by the bank about them be deleted or destroyed, save that which must be retained under law.
9. The Government will guarantee Australians a 'banking institution of last resort' so that no Australian may be permanently unable to possess a bank account.

from 27 citizens (Petition No. EN5342)
Health Care
Save our local pharmacies and local health issues.
The Government's policy to allow 60-day dispensing will place millions of Australians at risk. This policy is rushed and the negative impacts far outweigh the benefits.

With over 20,000 jobs in jeopardy, over 600 pharmacies at risk of closure, and the inevitability of reduced opening hours, the fallout of 60-day dispensing will be nothing short of devastating. This is not scaremongering, it is a heartbreaking reality.

from 28 citizens (Petition No. EN5343)
Myanmar
The Myanmar military is the primary cause of 70 years of political, economic, and humanitarian crises in Myanmar.

Since the February 2021 coup, the military has murdered over 3819 people, arrested over 23,980, many of whom have been subject to torture and sexual assault, including women and children, and caused the internal displacement of more than 1.5 million people.
Myanmar is ranked as one of the worst countries for political rights and civil liberties.

Over decades of military dictatorship, the military has attained a dominant position over Myanmar's economy through a complex web of commercial interests including their special relationship with state-owned enterprises. This has enriched the military leadership and provides the financial resources needed for its activities including its current terror campaign against the people.

The key recommendation of the UN Independent International Fact-Finding Mission on Myanmar was for the economic isolation of and disengagement from military-linked companies and state-owned enterprises.

In Australia's national interests—long term peace and prosperity—and in keeping with Australian values, Australia must give its full support to promoting democracy in Myanmar by implementing this recommendation.

We therefore ask the House to sanction key Myanmar state-owned enterprises and banks, now under full junta control, and also the regime's key sources of revenue— including Myanmar Oil and Gas Enterprise, Myanma Mining Enterprises No. 1 & 2, Myanmar Pearl Enterprise, Myanmar Gems Enterprise, Myanmar Timber Enterprise, Myanmar Petrochemical Enterprise, Myanma Foreign Trade Bank, and Myanma Investment and Commercial Bank- in coordination with Australia's allies.
from 2,036 citizens (Petition No. EN5344)

from 37 citizens (Petition No. EN5345)
Eczema

Despite the high prevalence and burden of eczema in Australia, the condition is often dismissed as a superficial rash, leaving many to suffer in silence. A new report reveals that nearly three million Australians are living with eczema, making it one of our country's most common chronic health conditions.

Eczema causes pain, distress and sleep disturbances leading to anxiety, depression and even suicidal ideation. Eczema also results in absenteeism from school and work, costing the economy $4 billion a year. Despite this, many Australians struggle to see a specialist due to a nationwide shortage of dermatologists, leading to suboptimal care, including the underuse of topical corticosteroids resulting in avoidable disease flares.

The financial burden on Australians is considerable, including costs associated with hospital visits, creams and medications, leading three quarters of Australians with eczema to say they use savings, borrow money, and spend less on food and other essentials so they can pay for eczema management. It is time for a long-term, nationwide plan to improve the care and management of Australians with eczema.

We therefore ask the House to support the formation of a National Eczema Strategy to ensure all Australians impacted by eczema receive the same high-quality standard of care, regardless of where they live.

PETITIONS
Responses
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I present the following 35 ministerial responses to petitions previously presented:
Infrastructure: Sport
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 26 July 2023 regarding the petition submitted to the Minister for Sport on 7 November 2022 for a large-scale arena in Canberra (EN4104).
I understand an Australian Government response to the petition is outstanding and the petition has been referred to me as the responsible Minister.

The petition requests the House of Representatives support the development of a large-scale arena in Canberra. Should these types of projects be identified as a priority for federal funding by the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) Government, the Australian Government would consider them through the usual Budget processes.

The Australian Government continues to work closely with the ACT Government on its infrastructure priorities. Concerns on ACT Government infrastructure priorities should be raised through the ACT Legislative Assembly.
Thank you for taking the time to write to me on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government, Ms Catherine King
Visual Arts Industry: Film
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 7 November 2022 to the Hon Michelle Rowland MP, Minister for Communications, regarding Petition EN4114, requesting the establishment of a task force to fund and develop the feature film G.I. Jane 2. Your correspondence was referred to me, as this matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities.

The work of the Australian creative sector, including the screen industry, is essential. It's essential to our community, what it is to be Australian and to our economy. After extensive engagement and with the support of the Australian creative sector, I was pleased to release Revive: a place for every story, a story for every place—Australia's cultural policy for the next five years, with the Prime Minister, the Hon Anthony Albanese MP on 30 January 2023.
This landmark new policy is shaped around the five goals of Creative Australia, established when the Hon Julia Gillard was Prime Minister. Revive is available at www.arts.gov.au/culturalpolicy.

Consistent with Revive, the Australian Government provides significant support to the Australian screen industry, recognising the important role it plays in shaping Australia's national identity. The Australian Screen Production Incentive is the Government's primary mechanism for providing support to the screen industry. It provides tax incentives for film, television and other screen production in Australia and is available in three streams:

The Producer Offset, administered by Screen Australia, entitles a production company to a 40-per-cent rebate on qualifying Australian production expenditure on eligible feature films and 30 per cent on other formats (television, online, DVD) for productions with significant Australian content.

The Post Digital and Visual Effects (PDV) Offset, administered by the Office for the A1is in the Department of Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development, Communications and the Arts (my department), provides a 30-per-cent rebate on qualifying expenditure for productions undertaking PDV production in Australia. The expenditure threshold for eligibility is $500,000 expenditure on activities reasonably required to perform the PDV production in Australia.

The Location Offset, administered by the Office for the Arts in my department, provides a 16.5 per cent rebate on qualifying Australian production expenditure for eligible productions with a minimum Australian spend of $15 million.

In the 2023-24 Budget, the Government announced the Location Offset will increase to 30 per cent from 1 July 2023. This announcement delivers on the Government's commitment in Revive, Australia's Cultural Policy for the next five years, to encourage investment by large- budget screen productions in Australia. The increase to the Location Offset will secure Australia's competitive position in attracting large budget screen productions to film here and maintain our world-class reputation for filmmaking. It will also benefit the entire screen sector by providing greater employment and development opp011unities for our skilled screen workers.

Revive also committed to introducing requirements for Australian screen content on streaming platforms. This will make sure more Australian shows and movies are seen across streaming platforms. These requirements will be implemented as part of the Government's broader reforms to media legislation and are the joint responsibility of the Hon Michelle Rowland MP, Minister for Communications, and myself as the Minister for the Arts.

Screen Australia is the Government's primary agency for supporting Australian film, television, documentary and digital media makers, through direct investment in screen development and production. Screen Australia offers funding to support the development, production and marketing of Australian screen content, as well as for the development of Australian talent and screen production businesses. More information is available at www.screenaustralia.gov.au/funding-and-support, or the agency can be contacted by email at info@screenaustralia.gov.au or by phone on 02 8113 5800.

These measures will build on the significant support the Government already provides for the production of screen content in Australia. In 2021-22, a total of $756 million was invested in the screen sector by the Government through direct funding or incentives. They will allow us to produce even more Australian stories told by Australians, and even more content filmed in Australia using the craft and skills of our dedicated screen professionals.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN4114 to the Australian Government's attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for the Arts, Mr Burke
Political Advertising
Dear Chair

Thank you for the email of 7 November 2022 which was received on 25 July 2023, regarding Petition EN4204—Paul Fletcher MP—Minister for Communications' response (MS21- 002610) to EN3329, EN3264, EN3288, EN3296, EN3328.
The Spam Act 2003 regulates the sending of unsolicited commercial electronic messages that seek to offer, adve1iise, supply or promote goods, services, land or business or investment opportunities.

The Do Not Call Register Act 2006 prevents organisations calling a number for telemarketing if the number is on the Register. Telemarketing is any call where the caller is aiming to sell, advertise or promote goods and services.

The Privacy Act 1988 (the Privacy Act) currently contains an exemption for members of an Australian Parliament, local government councillors and registered political parties, and their volunteers and contractors, in relation to specified kinds of political acts and practices.

On 16 February 2023, the Attorney-General, the Hon Mark Dreyfus KC, MP released the Privacy Act Review Report. Chapter 8 of the report examines the political exemption from the Privacy Act and proposes a number of restrictions to this exemption, including allowing individuals to opt out of receiving targeted advertising from a political entity.
Thank you for taking the time to write on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Ms Rowland
Taiwan
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 7 November 2022 regarding petition EN4268 that you presented in the House to formally recognise Taiwan and commit to its protection against Chinese aggression.

Australia and Taiwan share an interest in a rules-based, open, inclusive and stable Indo-Pacific region. Australia values our deep and productive unofficial relationship with Taiwan, underpinned by strong cultural, economic and people to people ties. Australia also works to support Taiwan's participation in international organisations and conferences where appropriate. The Australian Government does not, however, recognise the Republic of China as a sovereign state.

I have said publicly that a combination of factors, including Russia's illegal and immoral invasion of Ukraine, and the risk of miscalculation, comprise the most confronting circumstances that Australia has faced in decades.

Australia opposes any unilateral change to the status quo in the Taiwan Strait and recognises that a conflict over Taiwan would be catastrophic for all. Australia will continue to call for cross-Strait issues to be resolved peacefully through dialogue without the threat or use of force or coercion.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong
Gambling
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your email of 7 November 2022 concerning Petition EN4272—Request to amend the Interactive Gambling Act 2001 to include games containing loot boxes, in-game currencies operating secondary markets and microtransactions. I note that due to a technical issue, this petition was received in my office on 25 July 2023. apologise for the delay in replying.

On 15 September 2022, the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Social Policy and Legal Affairs (the Committee) launched an inquiry into online gambling and its impacts on those experiencing gambling harm. While the inquiry examined online gambling broadly, under the terms of reference the inquiry also examined the appropriateness of the definition of 'gambling service' in the Interactive Gambling Act 2001 and whether it should be amended to capture additional gambling-like activities in computer games including loot boxes and social casino games. The Committee received 161 submissions and held 13 public hearings with a variety of research, industry, community and government representatives.

On 28 June 2023 the Committee released their report' You win some, you lose more'. The Committee did not recommend amending the definition of 'gambling service' to capture loot boxes and simulated gambling. It recommended additional consumer protection measures for computer games containing these products, including default spending controls, tightening of simulated gambling advertising and more transparency on the odds of obtaining rewards from loot boxes. The Government is currently considering the Committee's recommendations and will respond in due course.

On 29 March 2023, I announced the Government's intention to seek agreement of the states and territories to introduce a mandatory minimum classification of R 18+ (Restricted to persons 18 and over) for games which contain simulated gambling and M (Mature—not recommended for persons under 15 years) for computer games containing loot boxes that can be purchased.

In its report, the Committee acknowledged the Government's proposed mandatory minimum classifications as an important first step in the regulation of gambling-like products in computer games. The Government is also exploring a number of consumer protection measures to further assist the Australian community to make informed choices about these products.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Ms Rowland
Russia
Dear Chair

Thank you for conveying a petition that calls for a ban on Australian companies and individuals from obtaining or supplying goods or services, investing or otherwise, with Russian Federation-based entities.

Australia condemns Russia's illegal, immoral invasion of Ukraine. We are working closely with Five Eyes, G7 and other partners to impose significant economic and political costs on Russia and those supporting its invasion.

The Government continues to expand Australia's comprehensive suite of sanctions and trade measures against Russia. We have imposed more than 1,100 targeted financial sanctions, and a range of import and export bans. Australia has banned the import of Russian refined petroleum, coal, gas and gold, and the export to Russia of alumina, bauxite and certain luxury goods. At the G7 Leaders' Summit in May 2023, Prime Minister Albanese also announced a ban on the export of all machinery and related parts to Russia and areas temporarily under Russian control, which will be implemented shortly.
Australia has also imposed an additional 35 percent tariff on the import of goods produced in Russia or Belarus. In tandem, we have waived tariffs on Ukrainian-produced goods imported to Australia.

These measures have been carefully calibrated to deny Russia access to our markets and ensure Australia does not inadvertently fund Russia's war machine. As a result, Australia's previously limited trade with Russia has declined to negligible levels. From January 2023 to June 2023, Australia's imports from Russia were down 99.96 per cent and Australian exports to Russia were down 99.99 per cent, compared to the same period two years prior.

Sanctions are a foreign policy tool to influence state behaviour short of armed force. Appropriately targeted sanctions, imposed in conjunction with other diplomatic levers, can effect positive change.

Russia's economy faces a long, slow grind. Sanctions and Russia's partial mobilisation are disrupting and diverting economic resources, contributing to a contraction of Russia's GDP by 2.1 per cent in 2022. Looking forward, Russia's isolation from Western markets will see its productivity decline further, limiting the economic resources it can commit to its illegal war on Ukraine.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong (Petition No. EN4276)
Ukraine
Dear Chair
Thank you for your email regarding petition EN4279 calling for Australia to review—and increase—the amount of military support we provide Ukraine.

Australia unequivocally supports Ukraine's sovereignty and territorial integrity. As a true and reliable partner, we continue to play our part to uphold the UN Charter, international law and the rules-based order. Australia's objective, along with our partners, is to empower Ukraine to end the war on its own terms.

It is in this context that Australia has committed approximately $890 million in important defence, economic and emergency humanitarian assistance to Ukraine. This has included around $710 million in military assistance. Most recently the Prime Minister committed a further 30 Bushmasters to Ukraine, taking our total contribution to 120. This builds on other tranches of recent military support, including the gifting of 70 highly capable military vehicles, and the supply of vital 105mm and 155mm ammunition.
Australia's assistance is a critical support to Ukraine's defence. The Government remains steadfast in its commitment to empowering Ukraine to resolve this war on its own terms.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong
Mental Health
Dear Ms Templeman,

span.span: PETITION EN4294—DEDICATED PTSD COUNSELLING FOR GENERATIONAL VICTIMS

p.span: Thank you for your correspondence originally dated 7 November 2022, re-sent 25 July 2023, regarding Petition Ministerial Referral EN4294. I note that the original email of 7 November 2022 was not received owing to a technical error at the Committee.

I recognise the concerns of the petitioner regarding the impact that military service can have on family members, including children of veterans and first responders. While 'generational PTSD' is not a term used by the Department of Veterans' Affairs (DVA), 'intergenerational trauma' is a recognised form of trauma when the experience and consequences of surviving a traumatic event is passed from one generation to the next.
A literature review of veteran intergenerational trauma undertaken by Phoenix Australia for DVA in 2022 found that:
The majority of the literature findings focus on intergenerational trauma transmission from military fathers, with very little evidence on transmission from military mothers;
Overall, there are direct and indirect impacts of parental trauma and associated mental health issues on children, which include:
Direct negative psychosocial and behavioural effects, higher risk of maltreatment, and mental and physical health problems.
Indirect parenting issues related to parent satisfaction, stress, practices, and behaviours.
Indirect family functioning issues related to family maladjustment and sibling disharmony.
Indirect parent-child relationship issues related to attachment and parental relationship styles.

Other than one study with young children and one with adult children which suggest that parental posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) differentially impacts male and female children, how the impacts differ between the genders is largely unknown.

It should also be noted that parental experiences of trauma do not always negatively impact children. Where there are impacts, DVA is able to provide services and support that respond to the needs of the individual.

Open Arms- Veterans & Families Counselling (Open Arms) is a leading provider of military-aware and trauma-informed mental health and counselling services to Australia's defence and veteran community. Open Arms provides mental health counselling, relationship counselling, peer support services and group programs for people with Australian Defence Force (ADF) service (current and former serving members) and their immediate families. This includes the young and adult children of veterans.

Open Arms promotes military-aware services by employing counsellors and peer workers with a history of military service, and/or experience as a family member or carer of a veteran. The services provided by Open Arms have been developed as a result of 40 years' experience in providing mental health services to veterans, their partners and their younger and adult children.

Open Arms operates within a context of trauma-informed practice to provide specialised PTSD treatment services and a range of other supports for veterans and their families who have experienced trauma and generational trauma. Open Arms' support for partners and children of veterans includes referral for psychiatric assessment to inform treatment planning to ensure that Open Arms interventions are appropriately tailored to the client.

In addition to the support provided through Open Arms, DVA also funds the Australian Kookaburra Kids Foundation to deliver their 'Defence Kids' program across Australia. The 2022-23 Budget provided $13.7 million over three years from 2022-23 to support this program in recognition that children in Defence and veteran families can often live with additional challenges to their civilian peers. This funding will support a focus on children of ex-serving members who may be more vulnerable following their parent's separation from the ADF and the loss of their Defence community support system.
Thank you for taking the time to bring this matter to my attention. I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours faithfully,
from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Mr Keogh
Assange, Mr Julian Paul
Dear Chair
Thank you for the referral of petition EN4310 regarding the extradition of Julian Assange.

I understand there is strong interest in Mr Assange's case and a depth of community sentiment. The Australian Government has been clear in its view that Mr Assange's case has dragged on for long enough and should be brought to a close. The Prime Minister and I have expressed this view to the governments of the United Kingdom and United States.

As we do for other Australians facing legal proceedings overseas, the Australian Government is following Mr Assange's case closely and offering consular assistance to him. The Australian Government will continue to convey its expectations that Mr Assange is entitled to due process, humane and fair treatment, access to proper medical care and access to his legal team.

The Australian Government is unable to intervene in another country's legal or court processes, just as they are unable to intervene in Australia's. While we are doing what we can between the Australian Government and other governments concerned, there are limits until Mr Assange has concluded legal processes. In a comparable case the resolution by government was only possible once legal processes had been concluded.
Thank you for taking the time to present this petition.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong
Telecommunications: Social Media
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your letter dated 7 November 2022 but received by my office on 26 July, on behalf of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Petitions, concerning petition EN4314 which calls for social media to be banned for children under 18.

I acknowledge community concern about children spending time on social media and its impact on their mental and physical health. The Government leads a number of measures to help Australian children stay safe online. The Government supports safe and responsible use of social media, where young people are able to enjoy the benefits of the internet and connect to their peers online. The view of the Australian Government is that banning social media for those under 18 would not be a prop01iionate response.

The Government considers that parents and carers are best placed to make decisions about their children's use of technology. Accordingly, the Government focusses on empowering parents and carers to make educated and informed decisions.

The Government invests in assisting parents, carers and children to stay safe online. The Government has delivered on its election commitment to provide $6 million over three years for the national rollout of eSmart digital and media literacy products, developed by the Alannah & Madeline Foundation. Secondary schools across Australia can access free online media literacy resources to equip high school students with critical skills to interpret what they read and view online. More information about the eSmart products can be found at www.alanahandmadeline.org.au/what-we-do/prevention-programs/esmart.

The Online Safety Act 2021 supports Australians online by providing the eSafety Commissioner with powers to crack down on cyberbullying, toxic online abuse, harmful content and the non-consensual sharing of intimate images. The cyberbullying scheme for Australian children provides the eSafety Commissioner with powers to order the removal of cyberbullying material from a full range of online services where children are spending time. Further information about how the eSafety Commissioner can help is at www.esafety.gov.au/key-issues/cyberbullying.

There are a number of online and telephone resources that offer support for people experiencing online harms. The eSafety Commissioner has a full list of resources for young people and parents at www.esafety.gov.au/about-us/counselling-support-services. You can also call Lifeline on 13 11 14 at any time.

The eSafety Commissioner has up-to-date information about parental controls and software tools that allow parents to monitor and limit what their children do or see online, and set time limits on devices. Free online webinars, downloadable books, information sheets and resources with easy to follow advice can be found at www.esafety.gov.au/Qarents. The eSafety Commissioner maintains a range of supportive resources about the impacts of spending time online, with advice on how to recognise online harms and how to create healthy boundaries with technology. These resources can be found at www.esafety.gov.au.
Thank you for bringing the concerns of this petition to my attention. I hope the information in this response is of some help.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Ms Rowland
Brisbane: Infrastructure
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your letter received on 25 July 2023 enclosing petition EN4326, regarding integrated transport and flood resilience solutions for the western suburbs of Brisbane. I note the concerns and observations raised around the impact of flooding events on transport infrastructure in Brisbane, which resulted in isolation of some communities and restricted access to essential goods and emergency/medical services.

The Australian Government recognises that Australia is facing more challenging natural disasters than ever before. Close to 70 per cent of Australians were impacted by storms, floods, cyclones and bushfires in 2022 alone.

On 1 September 2022 the Australian Government established the National Emergency Management Agency (NEMA) to create a single, enduring, end-to-end agency to better respond to emergencies, help communities recover, and prepare Australia for future disasters. NEMA provides national leadership and strategic oversight across the disaster management continuum, while collaborating across sectors and all levels of government to strengthen resilience.

Planning for, and responding to disasters is the responsibility of the state and territory governments. The primary way in which the Australian Government supports states and territories with the costs of providing relief and recovery assistance to communities is through the jointly-funded Disaster Recovery Funding Arrangements (DRFA).

Under the DRFA, jurisdictions determine the type and level of assistance to make available following a disaster. Importantly jurisdictions are not bound by the DRFA, and can make available whatever assistance they deem necessary, regardless of whether it is eligible for cost sharing under the DRFA. Programs funded through the DRFA in Queensland are administered by the Queensland Government.
Similarly, local governments are largely responsible for the day-to-day management of local road networks, including road safety, road funding, road maintenance, and heavy vehicle access.

Road funding for councils is provided by the Australian Government though a number of mechanisms, including the identified Local Roads component of the Financial Assistance Grants, the Roads to Recovery Program, the Black Spots Program and the Local Roads and Community Infrastructure program.

As the matters raised in this petition fall within the responsibility of the state and local governments in Queensland, interested members of affected communities may wish to raise the concerns highlighted in petition EN4326 with the Queensland Government, Brisbane City Council, or their local State Member of Parliament.
Thank you again for bringing petition EN4326 and the signatories' concerns to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Emergency Management, Senator WATT
Human Rights: Kashmir
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence regarding petition number EN4356, concerning the situation in Jammu and Kashmir.
The Australian Government values human dignity and expects all countries to promote, protect and respect human rights.

The Australian Government regularly engages with our Indian counterparts on human rights. India understands our strong position on such matters. When Australia and India have concerns with one another, we raise those concerns respectfully and directly.

Australia encourages the peaceful settlement of the final status of Jammu and Kashmir, underscored by the protection of human rights to ensure stability and economic recovery. Ultimately, the Kashmir dispute is a bilateral matter for India and Pakistan to resolve peacefully through dialogue.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong
Foot-and-Mouth Disease
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence of 7 November 2022 concerning petition number EN4368 regarding the enforcement of biosecurity measures to keep Australia free of foot-and-mouth disease (FMD).

In response to the outbreak of FMD in Indonesia, the Albanese Government has committed to long-term sustainable funding for biosecurity through new investments which will bolster Australia's strongest ever response to an exotic biosecurity threat. The Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has also strengthened biosecurity measures to protect Australia from an FMD incursion, including:
placing a ban on the importation of meat products for personal use from all countries which are not recognised by Australia as FMD free
heightening border activities, including new biosecurity officers in airports and mail centres, wider screening of passengers, luggage, parcels and postage in airports and mail centres
increasing vigilance across all flights arriving from Indonesia, including Bali
informing travellers and the public of FMD risk and their biosecurity responsibilities, including through specific FMD advice on every inbound plane from Indonesia
relocating biosecurity detector dogs to key airports
deploying sanitation foot mats in Australia's international airports
reviewing import permits for products from Indonesia that may carry FMD and a suspension of those of concern

providing assistance to Indonesia to help control the spread of FMD through the region. Assistance includes advice from Australian technical experts, supply of vaccines, protective equipment and disinfectants, and training of staff on the ground and offers of financial support. This is in addition to assistance already being provided to combat lumpy skin disease (LSD), that has also been detected in Indonesia.

The Albanese Government will continue to take advice from biosecurity experts in applying biosecurity measures appropriate to the risk of FMD entering Australia. The government will also continue surveillance activities and will prosecute breaches of biosecurity measures to the full extent of the law.
Thank you again for raising this matter with me and for the valuable work undertaken by the Committee.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, Senator Watt
Australian National Flag
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your email received 25 July 2023 regarding petition EN4369 which requests the Australian Government change the Australian National Flag and state flags to remove the Union Jack.

The Australian National Flag is Australia's foremost national symbol and is an expression of Australian identity and pride. The flag is paraded by our defence forces and is displayed by national sporting groups, community groups and private citizens.
The Flags Act 1953 requires a poll of all Australians before the design of the Australian National Flag can be changed. At this stage, the Australian Government has no plans to conduct a poll.

The design of each state flag is the responsibility for the relevant state government. If the petitioners wish to suggest a change to a state flag it would be appropriate to contact the relevant state premier with their suggestion.
Thank you for bringing this petition to the Australian Government's attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister to the Prime Minister, Mr Gorman
Australian National Anthem
Ms Templeman
Thank you for your email received 25 July 2023 regarding petition EN4444 which requests that the Australian Government change the Australian National Anthem to 'I Am Australian'.

The words and tune of the Australian National Anthem were proclaimed by the Governor-General of Australia on 19 April 1984, after extensive surveys of national opinion, starting in the 1970s. On 1 January 2021, the second line of the Anthem changed from 'For we are young and free' to 'For we are one and free.' This change was made to represent all Australians.
The Australian National Anthem remains widely accepted by Australians and it identifies Australia at home and overseas but anyone can enjoy other songs about Australia such as 'I Am Australian'.

While the Government has no plans to change this important national symbol at this time, debate around these matters in the wider community should be celebrated and encouraged as an important part of our democracy.
Thank you for bringing this petition to the Australian Government's attention.
from the Assistant Minister to the Prime Minister, Mr Gorman
Film and Video Industry
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your email of 8 November 2022 to the Hon Tony Burke MP, Minister for the Arts, concerning Petition EN4451, requesting the introduction of a new classification (C) for 'lack of consent' on all media containing depictions of non-consensual sexual acts. Minister Burke has forwarded the correspondence to me as the National Classification Scheme (NCS) falls within my portfolio. I note that due to a technical issue, this petition was received in my office on 25 July 2023. I apologise for the delay in responding.

Under the NCS the Classification Board (the Board), an independent statutory body, classifies films, computer games and certain publications, applying a classification rating (such as G or PG) and providing consumer advice about the content of the work. In deciding a rating, the Board must apply the National Classification Code, relevant sections of the Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Act 1995 (the Act) and the relevant classification guidelines.

The proposal to introduce a new classification category for 'lack of consent' would require amendment of the classification guidelines. Under the Intergovernmental Agreement on Censorship 1995, any change to the classification guidelines must be subject to a public submissions process and be unanimously agreed by state and territory ministers responsible for classification. The Government does not intend to propose a change to the classification categories at this time. Research conducted by my department in 2022 found high levels of community satisfaction with the current categories, and the 2020 Review of Australian classification regulation (the Stevens Review) recommended against changing the categories.

The Board has discretion to formulate consumer advice however it considers appropriate. The Board has an established practice for providing consumer advice about depictions of sexual violence, but would usually provide specific consumer advice on other non-consensual sexual acts only if they were assessed by the Board as being potentially harmful, disturbing or upsetting to viewers.

The Board has recently considered whether it should provide consumer advice about non- consensual sexual activity that may not be understood as sexual violence. In May 2023, the Board announced a number of enhancements to consumer advice to provide more detailed warnings to consumers about content of concern, however the Board has not elected to introduce additional consumer advice about 'lack of consent'.

In March 2023, the Government announced a two-stage process of reform to the NCS. In addition to regulatory arrangements, the second stage of reform will consider the appropriate scope and purpose of the NCS, including the role of classification in educating community members about matters such as consent.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention. I hope the information in this letter is of some assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Ms Rowland
Education
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 8 November 2022 regarding Petition Referral EN4467. I note there was significant delay in the petition being forwarded for my consideration, and that it was received by my office on 25 July 2023.

The Australian Government considers science and science literacy as essential knowledge to support Australia's prosperity. The Australian Curriculum (the Curriculum) provides students with the opportunity to learn about Science from Foundation to Year 10, which includes content covering the theory of evolution and learning about biology. This content can also be taught flexibly at the local level.

Education Ministers endorsed the revised version 9 of the Australian Curriculum on 1 April 2022. This Curriculum was developed through an extensive consultation process. As a result, it sets a high standard for educational achievement in Australia from Foundation to Year 10, and teaches essential content that students should learn. Further information about the updated Curriculum is available at www.v9.australiancurriculum.edu.au. Jurisdictions are implementing the new Curriculum according to the timelines and approaches set by each state and territory education authority from this year.

While the Australian Government takes a leadership role in matters of national education policy, the delivery of school education is a matter for state and territory government and non-government education authorities. The petitioner may wish to contact their state or territory Education Minister to discuss their concerns. Contact details are enclosed.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely

Australian Broadcasting Corporation
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your email of 17 May 2023 regarding Petition EN4823, which calls for the House to organise an independent review into the ABC's conduct and perceived left-wing bias.

The Australian Government provides an overall level of funding to the ABC. However, the Parliament has guaranteed the broadcaster's independence so that its editorial decisions can be free from political interference.
Concerned members of the public are encouraged to contact the ABC to put forward their views. Complaints can be submitted to the ABC using its web form at abc.net.au/contact/com12lain.htm.

Direct contact is the best way to make sure the ABC is aware of these concerns, and is given an opportunity to respond. The ABC is also accountable to the Parliament through appearances before committees, including Senate Estimates, and through the production of annual reports.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Michelle Rowland
Medicare
Dear Chair
